choices.text: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD)
Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD)
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his mother, who is concerned about her son's behavior. She reports that he has been having difficulty concentrating at school, often interrupts others, and is consistently disorganized. The boy's teacher has also noticed these behaviors and has expressed concern about his academic performance. The symptoms have persisted for more than 6 months and began before he turned 6 years old. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD).

 

Option C: 

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), as he is displaying symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity that have persisted for more than 6 months and began before the age of 6. ADHD is a neurodevelopmental disorder that affects children and adolescents, often continuing into adulthood.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Generalized Anxiety Disorder is less likely, as the patient's symptoms primarily involve inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, rather than excessive worry and anxiety.

 

Option B. Oppositional Defiant Disorder is characterized by a pattern of angry, irritable mood, and defiant behavior toward authority figures. While the patient may display some disruptive behaviors, his main concerns are inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, which are more consistent with ADHD.

 

Option D. Autism Spectrum Disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by deficits in social communication and interaction, as well as restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities. The patient's symptoms do not include these core features, making ADHD a more likely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder that presents before the age of 12 and is characterized by inattention (Difficulty in giving close attention to details, making frequent mistakes in school work, being distractible, frequent shifts from one activity to another without finishing the task), hyperactivity (Keeps on roaming in the class, disturbs other students too), impulsivity (Can’t wait for his turn, answer even before the question is complete) and sometimes destructive behaviour, irritability. For the diagnosis, symptoms must be present in two or more settings (e.g., at school and at home), interfere with or reduce the quality of social, academic, or occupational functioning, and cannot be better explained by another mental disorder.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 132-134.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with his mother, who is concerned about his school performance. The boy has difficulty concentrating, is easily distracted, and has trouble following instructions. The teacher also reports that he is often restless and fidgety in class. After a thorough evaluation, the pediatrician diagnoses the boy with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Which of the following is the first-line pharmacological treatment for ADHD?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methylphenidate

 

Option B: 

 

Methylphenidate is a first-line pharmacological treatment for ADHD in children and adolescents. It is a central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that increases dopamine and norepinephrine levels in the brain, leading to improvements in attention, focus, and impulse control. Studies have shown that methylphenidate is effective in reducing ADHD symptoms in approximately 70% to 80% of patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that can be used as a second-line treatment for ADHD, particularly when stimulants are not well-tolerated, contraindicated, or have an inadequate response. Atomoxetine is less effective than stimulants but may be a useful alternative for some patients.

 

Option C. Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that can be used as an adjunctive treatment for ADHD when there is a partial response or intolerance to stimulants. It may also be helpful in managing comorbid conditions such as tics or sleep disturbances. However, it is not considered a first-line treatment for ADHD.

 

Option D. Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is primarily used to treat depression and anxiety disorders. Although SSRIs may help with some of the emotional and behavioral symptoms associated with ADHD, they are not considered effective for the core symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. Thus, fluoxetine is not a first-line treatment for ADHD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pharmacotherapy with stimulant drugs is considered to be the first line treatment of ADHD. Methylphenidate is the drug of choice.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 135.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is diagnosed with ADHD. His parents report that he has difficulty focusing, impulsivity, and hyperactivity. He has tried a trial of methylphenidate, but experienced severe side effects such as irritability, insomnia, and loss of appetite. The patient was also tried on amphetamine-dextroamphetamine, but similar side effects were noted. What is the most appropriate next pharmacological treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atomoxetine

 

Option A:

 

The most appropriate next pharmacological treatment for this patient would be Atomoxetine. ADHD is commonly treated with stimulant medications like methylphenidate and amphetamine-dextroamphetamine, which the patient has tried but was unable to tolerate due to severe side effects. 

 

Atomoxetine is a non-stimulant medication, which is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI). It is a second-line treatment for ADHD when patients are unable to tolerate stimulants. Atomoxetine has a different side effect profile than stimulant medications and is less likely to cause the irritability, insomnia, and loss of appetite that the patient experienced.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Modafinil is a wakefulness-promoting agent that is mainly used to treat narcolepsy and other sleep disorders. While it has some evidence for use in ADHD, it is not FDA-approved for this indication and is not a first or second-line treatment.

 

Option C. Pemoline is an older stimulant medication that is no longer recommended for ADHD treatment due to its association with hepatotoxicity.

 

Option D. Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant, which is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI). It may be considered as an off-label treatment for ADHD, but it is not as effective as atomoxetine and may not be the best choice for a patient who has not responded well to stimulant medications. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atomoxetine is an appropriate next step in pharmacological treatment for ADHD in a patient who has not tolerated or responded well to stimulant medications. It is a non-stimulant option that can be effective in managing ADHD symptoms without the same side effect profile as stimulant medications.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 136-137.

choices.text: There is a strong genetic component in the etiology of ASD.
Vaccinations are a well-established cause of ASD.
Boys are more likely to be diagnosed with ASD than girls.
Early intervention and behavioral therapy can improve outcomes in children with ASD.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents. They report that he has difficulty in social interactions and prefers to play alone. He has a limited range of interests and engages in repetitive behaviors. His language development seems delayed. They are concerned about his behavior and are seeking advice. Which of the following statements about autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vaccinations are a well-established cause of ASD.

 

Option B:

 

Vaccinations are not a well-established cause of ASD. This statement is false. Numerous studies have refuted the claim that there is a link between vaccinations, specifically the MMR vaccine, and the development of ASD. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. There is a strong genetic component in the etiology of ASD. Twin studies have shown that there is a higher concordance rate for ASD in monozygotic twins compared to dizygotic twins. Additionally, genetic mutations and chromosomal abnormalities have been identified in individuals with ASD.

 

Option C. Boys are more likely to be diagnosed with ASD than girls. This statement is true and the prevalence of ASD is higher in boys than girls. 

 

Option D. Early intervention and behavioral therapy can improve outcomes in children with ASD. Early intervention programs that focus on behavioral therapy, social skills training, and communication development can help children with ASD to develop essential life skills and improve their overall functioning. These interventions can lead to better outcomes in terms of social integration, academic achievement, and quality of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is important to understand that vaccines do not cause Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). There is a strong genetic basis for ASD, and boys are more frequently diagnosed than girls. Early intervention and behavioral therapy are crucial in managing ASD and can lead to better outcomes for affected individuals.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 130-131.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and is referred to a child psychiatrist for management. He has significant difficulties with social interaction and communication, as well as repetitive behaviors and restricted interests. He also demonstrates irritability, aggression, and self-injurious behavior. Which of the following medications is most likely to be effective in managing the irritability and aggression associated with his ASD?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risperidone

 

Option C:

 

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of irritability associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in children and adolescents. It can help manage symptoms such as aggression, self-injurious behavior, and severe tantrums. Risperidone works by affecting the levels of neurotransmitters in the brain, which can help to stabilize mood and reduce behavioral issues in children with ASD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) primarily used for the treatment of depression and anxiety disorders. While SSRIs can sometimes be used in ASD to manage associated anxiety or depression, they are not typically the first choice for irritability and aggression in ASD.

 

Option B. Methylphenidate: Methylphenidate is a stimulant medication commonly used to treat Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). While it can help with focus and attention in children with ADHD, it is not primarily used for irritability and aggression in ASD.

 

Option D. Atomoxetine: Atomoxetine is a non-stimulant medication used to treat ADHD. Like methylphenidate, it is not the first choice for managing irritability and aggression in children with ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that has been specifically approved for the treatment of irritability associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in children and adolescents, including symptoms such as aggression, self-injurious behavior, and temper tantrums.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 128.

choices.text: More than 75% of patients have seizures
Stereotypic hand movements

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her mother. The mother reports that her daughter had normal development until the age of 18 months, after which she began to lose her previously acquired motor and language skills. The girl now has poor eye contact, and her mother has noticed repetitive hand-wringing movements. Which of the following is NOT a feature of the girl's most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Macrocephaly

 

Option A:

 

The clinical presentation described is consistent with Rett Syndrome, a neurodevelopmental disorder that primarily affects females. Rett Syndrome is characterized by a period of normal development followed by a regression in skills, loss of purposeful hand movements replaced by stereotypic movements such as hand-wringing, autistic-like behaviors, and a variety of other neurological symptoms. One of the hallmark features is the development of repetitive, stereotypic hand movements. Seizures and autistic-like features are also common in individuals with Rett Syndrome.

 

Macrocephaly, or an abnormally large head size, is NOT a feature of Rett Syndrome. In fact, individuals with Rett Syndrome often have a deceleration of head growth leading to microcephaly (an abnormally small head) as they age, not macrocephaly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. More than 75% of patients with Rett Syndrome may develop seizures throughout their lifetime, making it a common feature of the disorder.

 

Option C. Stereotypic hand movements, such as handwringing, are one of the hallmark features of Rett Syndrome and are often one of the key symptoms that lead to its diagnosis.

 

Option D. Autistic-like features, including poor eye contact and social withdrawal, are common in the early stages of Rett Syndrome, although the disorder has a distinct progression and differs from classic autism spectrum disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rett Syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by normal early growth and development followed by a slowing of development, loss of purposeful use of the hands, distinctive hand movements, slowed brain and head growth, problems with walking, seizures, and intellectual disability. Macrocephaly is not a feature of Rett Syndrome; instead, microcephaly that becomes apparent as the child grows is more characteristic.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page 1166.

choices.text: MECP2 gene mutation
FMR1 gene mutation
PSEN1 gene mutation
HTT gene mutation

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents. They report that she had normal development until 18 months of age, but since then, they have noticed regression in her motor and language skills. The girl also exhibits repetitive hand movements, such as wringing or clapping. The pediatrician suspects Rett syndrome. Which of the following genetic mutations is most associated with Rett syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MECP2 gene mutation

 

Option A:

 

MECP2 gene mutation is the most commonly associated genetic mutation in Rett syndrome, which is an X-linked neurodevelopmental disorder that primarily affects females. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. FMR1 gene mutation is associated with Fragile X syndrome, another X-linked neurodevelopmental disorder that primarily affects males. 

 

Option C. PSEN1 gene mutation is associated with early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease, an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder.

 

Option D. HTT gene mutation is associated with Huntington's disease, an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder.

 

Educational objective:

 

Rett’s syndrome is most commonly caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page 1166.

choices.text: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
Autism spectrum disorder (ASD)

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents, who are concerned about his recent behavior. They report that over the past six months, the boy has been repeatedly clearing his throat, blinking excessively, and occasionally jerking his head. These behaviors have become more frequent and have started to interfere with his daily activities and school performance. The parents also mention that the boy occasionally makes inappropriate sounds or uses inappropriate words in social situations, which has led to some social difficulties. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tourette's syndrome

 

Option C: 

 

Tourette's syndrome is the most likely diagnosis, as it is characterized by multiple motor tics and at least one vocal tic. Tics are sudden, rapid, nonrhythmic movements or sounds that are repetitive and involuntary.  This patient has history suggestive of motor tics (blinking excessively, and occasionally jerking his head) and vocal tic (repeatedly clearing his throat), which is consistent with the diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) presents with repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and behaviors (compulsions) performed to alleviate the anxiety caused by the obsessions. Although the boy's behaviors are repetitive, they do not seem to be driven by obsessions, making OCD less likely.

 

Option B. Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is characterized by inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity. While some repetitive behaviors might be present in ADHD, the specific tics and inappropriate vocalizations described in the case are not typical for ADHD.

 

Option D. Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction, communication difficulties, and restricted or repetitive behaviors. Although repetitive behaviors are present in ASD, the specific tics and vocalizations described in the case are not characteristic of ASD.

 

Educational objective:

 

Tourette’s syndrome is characterized by multiple motor tics and one or more vocal tics. Comorbidities include ADHD (most common), OCD and depression. Onset usually occurs by 4-6 years of age and peaks by 10-12 years of age and remits by adolescence or young adulthood (in half to two third of cases). It is more frequently seen in males than females. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 160.

choices.text: Habit reversal training (HRT)
Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS)

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy has been diagnosed with Tourette's syndrome. His parents are interested in non-pharmacological treatment options to help manage their son's tics. Which of the following interventions has shown evidence of effectiveness in reducing tic severity in individuals with Tourette's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Habit reversal training (HRT)

 

Option C:

 

Habit reversal training (HRT) is a behavioral intervention designed to help individuals with tic disorders, such as Tourette's syndrome, recognize and manage their tics. It involves teaching patients to become aware of their tics and replace them with less noticeable or disruptive behaviors. Several studies have shown HRT to be effective in reducing tic severity in individuals with Tourette's syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be effective for treating various psychiatric disorders, however, there is limited evidence supporting the use of CBT specifically for reducing tic severity in individuals with Tourette's syndrome.

 

Option B. Biofeedback involves the use of electronic monitoring to help patients gain awareness and control over certain physiological processes. Although it has been used for other conditions, there is insufficient evidence supporting its effectiveness for Tourette's syndrome.

 

Option D. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a non-invasive brain stimulation technique that has been used for various neurological and psychiatric disorders. However, there is limited evidence supporting its effectiveness for treating Tourette's syndrome, and it is not considered a first-line non-pharmacological intervention.

 

Educational objective:

 

Treatment of Tourette’s syndrome include:

 

  • Habit reversal therapy (In habit reversal therapy, patients learn to identify the urge that precedes tics. When they sense this urge, they perform a voluntary behaviour (e.g., slow rhythmic breathing) instead of engaging in the tic)
  • Clonidine and guanfacine (first-line pharmacological management)
  • Risperidone
  • Haloperidol, Pimozide (FDA approved)

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 160.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who reports that he has been experiencing sudden and involuntary movements and vocalizations for the past year. His mother notes that he frequently clears his throat and makes grunting sounds, as well as jerking his head and shoulders without any apparent reason. He has been increasingly embarrassed by these symptoms and has started to avoid social situations. The boy's symptoms are most consistent with Tourette's syndrome. Which of the following medications is considered the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clonidine

 

Option D:

 

Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist and is considered the first-line treatment for tics associated with Tourette's syndrome. It helps to reduce the frequency and severity of tics, often with fewer side effects than other medications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) may be helpful in managing comorbid OCD symptoms in some patients with Tourette's syndrome, however, it is not the first-line treatment for tics associated with the condition.

 

Option B. Methylphenidate, a stimulant medication may be helpful for comorbid ADHD symptoms in patients with Tourette's syndrome, however, it is not considered first-line treatment for tics and may even exacerbate them in some cases.

 

Option C. Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic medication that can be used to treat severe or disabling tics in Tourette's syndrome. However, due to its potential side effects, such as weight gain and metabolic abnormalities, it is typically reserved for cases where first-line treatments have not been effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clonidine and guanfacine are commonly used first-line options for managing tic disorders in children, especially when minimizing side effects is a priority. It is effective in reducing the severity and frequency of tics and generally has a lower risk of significant side effects compared to antipsychotic medications. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 160.

choices.text: Oppositional defiant disorder
Intermittent explosive disorder

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents. They report that their son has been increasingly aggressive towards other children at school, often getting into physical altercations. He also steals items from the store and has been caught vandalizing property in the neighbourhood. His parents state that he shows no remorse for his actions and does not seem to care about the consequences. The boy has been exhibiting these behaviors for the past 18 months. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conduct disorder

 

Option B:

 

Conduct disorder is characterized by a repetitive and persistent pattern of behavior in which the individual violates the rights of others or age-appropriate societal norms, such as aggression towards people and animals, destruction of property, deceitfulness or theft, and serious violations of rules. The boy's persistent aggressive and destructive behaviors, along with his lack of remorse, are consistent with conduct disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, or vindictiveness however unlike conduct disorder, serious violations like theft, destruction etc are not seen. Although some symptoms may overlap with conduct disorder, the boy's aggressive and criminal behaviors point more towards conduct disorder.

 

Option C. Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is characterized by a pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development. While children with ADHD may sometimes display impulsive and aggressive behaviors, the primary symptoms of ADHD do not match the boy's presentation.

 

Option D. Intermittent explosive disorder involves recurrent behavioral outbursts representing a failure to control aggressive impulses, typically resulting in verbal or physical aggression towards property, animals, or other individuals. However, the boy's consistent pattern of antisocial behavior and lack of remorse is more characteristic of conduct disorder.

 

Educational objective:

 

Conduct disorder is characterised by a persistent pattern of ‘disregard for rights of others’ and aggressive and dissocial behaviour, and manifests with the following-

 

  • Stealing, repeated lying, aggression, bullying, cruelty towards animals, disobedience, running away from school
  •  High risk of later development of antisocial personality disorder

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 189.

choices.text: Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD)
Intermittent Explosive Disorder

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who reports that her son frequently argues with adults, refuses to follow rules, and deliberately annoys his siblings. His teacher also reports similar behaviour at school, where he often defies instructions and blames others for his mistakes. These behaviours have persisted for the last 12 months and are causing significant problems at home and school. The boy has no history of aggressive or violent behaviour. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD)

 

Option C:

 

Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD) is characterized by a pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, or vindictiveness lasting at least 6 months. The boy's persistent argumentative behavior, refusal to follow rules, and deliberate annoyance of others are consistent with ODD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. Although children with ADHD may have difficulty following rules, the primary issue is with attention and self-regulation, not the pattern of defiant behavior described in this case.

 

Option B. Conduct Disorder involves a repetitive and persistent pattern of behavior that violates the rights of others or major age-appropriate societal norms. This includes aggressive behavior, destruction of property, deceitfulness, and serious rule violations. The boy in this case does not exhibit these more severe behaviors.

 

Option D. Intermittent Explosive Disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of impulsive, aggressive, or violent behavior that is out of proportion to the triggering situation. The boy in this case does not exhibit aggressive or violent behavior, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational objective:

 

Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by negativistic and defiant behaviour towards adults and authority figures. It can be considered a milder form of conduct disorder,  unlike conduct disorder, there are no serious violations.


Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 187.

choices.text: Patients often exhibit repetitive hand-wringing movements.
There is usually a period of normal development followed by a loss of acquired skills.
It is most commonly caused by an autosomal dominant gene.

questions.text: A psychiatrist is discussing Rett's syndrome with a group of medical students. Which of the following statements regarding Rett's syndrome is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is most commonly caused by an autosomal dominant gene.

 

Option D:

 

Rett's syndrome is most commonly caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene located on the X chromosome, not by an autosomal dominant gene. The disorder is typically not inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern but instead occurs as a de novo (new) mutation. Rett's syndrome is classified as an X-linked dominant condition, which predominantly affects females. Males with the MECP2 mutation often experience more severe symptoms and may die in utero or in infancy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It primarily affects females: This is true because the MECP2 gene mutation causing Rett's syndrome is located on the X chromosome. Since females have two X chromosomes, they can survive with a single functional copy of the gene. Males have one X and one Y chromosome, so a mutation in their only MECP2 gene is usually lethal.

 

Option B. Patients often exhibit repetitive hand-wringing movements: This is a characteristic behavior of Rett's syndrome and is one of the main diagnostic features.

 

Option C. There is usually a period of normal development followed by a loss of acquired skills: Children with Rett's syndrome typically develop normally for the first 5 months before regressing, losing purposeful use of their hands, and often developing gait abnormalities and losing language skills.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rett's syndrome is a rare genetic disorder primarily affecting females, characterized by normal development till 5 months followed by deceleration of head circumference (resulting in microcephaly), loss of acquired hand skills and speech, poor gait, impairment in social interaction; restricted, repetitive behaviours & impairment of communication and language between 5-48 months. 75% of the patients have seizures. It is most commonly caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome. In DSM-5 and ICD-11, they are classified as autism spectrum disorders.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page 1166.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents. They report that he had been developing normally, acquiring speech and motor skills typical for his age. However, over the past few months, they have noticed a marked regression in his speech and motor abilities. He has become less interactive, has lost purposeful hand movements, and shows a reduced interest in play. His parents are extremely concerned. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with this child's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heller's Syndrome 

 

Option C:

 

The child's presentation of a marked regression in speech and motor abilities, loss of interactive behaviors, and reduced interest in play after a period of apparently normal development is most consistent with Heller's Syndrome, also known as Childhood Disintegrative Disorder. This rare condition is characterized by a significant loss of previously acquired developmental skills before the age of 10, following at least two years of normal development. The regression can affect language, social skills, motor skills, and play.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Asperger's Syndrome: This is characterized by difficulties in social interaction and nonverbal communication, alongside restricted and repetitive patterns of behavior and interests. It is not typically associated with a regression of skills.

 

Option B. Rett's Syndrome: This is almost exclusively seen in females. It is characterized by normal early growth and development till 5 months of age followed by a slowing of development and loss of purposeful use of the hands, distinctive hand movements, slowed brain and head growth, problems with walking, seizures, and intellectual disability.

 

Option D. Fragile X Syndrome: This is a genetic condition causing intellectual disability, behavioral and learning challenges, and various physical characteristics. It does not typically involve regression of previously acquired skills as described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heller's Syndrome, also known as Childhood Disintegrative Disorder, is characterized by normal development till 2 yrs followed by loss of acquired motor skills, social skills, bowel & bladder control, impairment in social interaction; restricted, repetitive behaviours & impairment of communication and language between 2-10 years. In DSM-5 and ICD-11, they are classified as autism spectrum disorders.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page 1166-1167.

choices.text: Normal cognitive and language development despite social challenges

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents. They report that their son has always had difficulty interacting with peers and often seems disinterested in making friends. However, he can speak in full sentences, has an extensive vocabulary, and demonstrates an intense interest in train schedules, often talking about them in great detail. His teachers report that academically, he is at grade level. Which of the following differentiates this boy's likely diagnosis from other types of autism spectrum disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Normal cognitive and language development despite social challenges

 

Option D:

 

The boy's presentation — difficulty in social interaction, specific intense interests, normal cognitive and language development, and being at grade level academically — is suggestive of Asperger's Syndrome. Asperger's Syndrome is differentiated from other types of autism spectrum disorders primarily by the presence of normal cognitive and language development. Individuals with Asperger's Syndrome typically do not have significant delays in cognitive abilities or language development. Instead, they often have specific, intense interests and significant challenges in social interactions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Presence of speech delay: Individuals with Asperger's Syndrome usually do not have a history of speech delay, which is more characteristic of other autism spectrum disorders.

 

Option B. Intellectual disability: Intellectual disability is not a defining feature of Asperger's Syndrome. In contrast, some individuals with other forms of autism spectrum disorder may have intellectual disabilities.

 

Option C. Lack of repetitive behaviors: Repetitive behaviors can be present in Asperger's Syndrome, as well as in other forms of autism spectrum disorders. It's not a distinguishing feature between Asperger's Syndrome and other autism spectrum disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asperger's syndrome, which is a type of autism spectrum disorder, is characterized by normal cognitive and language development but significant challenges in social interactions. In DSM-5 and ICD-11, they are classified as autism spectrum disorders.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page 1167-1168.

choices.text: Symptoms must be present before 7 years of age.
Symptoms cause significant impairment in two or more settings.
The presence of a comorbid learning disability.
A history of head trauma or injury.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns about his academic performance. She reports that her son is easily distracted, often forgets to complete his assignments, and has difficulty organizing tasks. The teacher also reports that the boy often leaves his seat, interrupts others, and acts impulsively. These behaviors have persisted for the last two years and are seen both at school and at home. Which of the following criteria is essential for the diagnosis of this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Symptoms cause significant impairment in two or more settings.

 

Options B:

 

The description of the 9-year-old boy's behavior is consistent with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). One of the essential criteria for diagnosing ADHD is that the symptoms cause significant impairment in two or more settings (e.g., at home, school, or in social situations). This criterion ensures that the behaviors are consistent and pervasive, rather than being situation specific.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Symptoms must be present before 7 years of age: This was an older criterion. The current Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) states that several symptoms must be present by age 12, not 7.

 

Option C. The presence of a comorbid learning disability: While children with ADHD may have a comorbid learning disability, it is not a requirement for the diagnosis of ADHD. Many children with ADHD do not have a learning disability.

 

Option D. A history of head trauma or injury: A history of head trauma or injury is not a criterion for the diagnosis of ADHD. ADHD is primarily a neurodevelopmental disorder with a basis in brain function and genetics, rather than being caused by external injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) requires that the symptoms cause significant impairment in two or more settings, such as at home, school, or in social interactions. This criterion is essential to confirm that the disorder is pervasive and not limited to a specific context. The symptoms should be present before the age of 12, according to DSM-5.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 134.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns regarding his academic performance and behaviour at school. The teacher reports that the child often seems distracted, frequently leaves his seat, and has difficulty waiting his turn in group activities. The psychiatrist, suspecting ADHD, contemplates the various pharmacological options available. In considering medications, the paediatrician recalls that one of the following drugs is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor. Which drug is it?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atomoxetine

 

Option B:

 

Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) and is used for the treatment of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Unlike stimulant medications such as methylphenidate and amphetamines, atomoxetine works by selectively inhibiting the reuptake of norepinephrine, a neurotransmitter associated with attention and impulsivity. Atomoxetine is particularly useful in patients with ADHD who may not respond well to stimulants, have a history of substance abuse, or have certain comorbid conditions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Methylphenidate: Methylphenidate is a stimulant medication that primarily works by increasing the levels of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain, but it is not classified as a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor.

 

Option C.  Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. It is used as a second-line treatment for ADHD. It is not an NRI.

 

Option D. Modafinil: Modafinil is another stimulant used primarily for conditions like narcolepsy. It is not an NRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor used for the treatment of ADHD. It is a non-stimulant medication option for patients with ADHD, especially those who may not be suitable candidates for stimulant medications.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 136-137.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is referred for an evaluation due to difficulties in learning and adapting to his environment. He has been struggling academically, and his teachers have noticed that he is not able to keep up with his peers in terms of cognitive and social skills. After a comprehensive assessment, his full-scale IQ is found to be 40. How would this child's intellectual disability be classified based on his IQ score?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moderate Intellectual Disability

 

Explanation:

 

Intellectual disability is classified based on the severity of cognitive impairment, which is often measured using IQ scores. The classification according to IQ scores is as follows:

 

  • Mild Intellectual Disability: IQ scores typically between 50-69.
  • Moderate Intellectual Disability: IQ scores typically between 35-49.
  • Severe Intellectual Disability: IQ scores typically between 20-34.
  • Profound Intellectual Disability: IQ scores below 20.

 

Given that the 10-year-old boy has a full-scale IQ of 40, his intellectual disability would be classified as "Moderate Intellectual Disability." This level of intellectual disability is characterized by noticeable limitations in cognitive functioning and in adaptive behavior, which covers everyday social and practical skills. Individuals with moderate intellectual disability require support for complex daily living tasks and academic skills.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the classification of intellectual disability, a full-scale IQ score of 40 falls within the range of "Moderate Intellectual Disability." This classification indicates significant limitations in intellectual and adaptive functioning, requiring support in academic, social, and practical aspects of daily life.

 

 

Ref: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page 156.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has been diagnosed with an intellectual disability and is currently being assessed to determine the most appropriate educational placement. He has significant difficulties in verbal and non-verbal communication, requires constant supervision for personal care, and has not developed any functional academic skills. His engagement in social interactions is limited, and he shows a preference for solitary activities. Based on his adaptive functioning and educational needs, what is the most likely severity of his intellectual disability?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe

 

Option C:

 

The description of the 15-year-old boy indicates significant limitations in several areas of functioning. His difficulties in verbal and non-verbal communication, need for constant supervision in personal care, with lack of functional academic skills, and limited social interactions suggest a level of impairment beyond mild or moderate intellectual disability.

 

Severe ID: Correct. Individuals may acquire limited communication skills and need support for      daily living activities. Academic skills are minimal to none, and they require extensive support. While constant supervision for personal care, doesn't necessarily indicate he needs continuous supervision for all aspects of life or life support which is seen in profound ID

 

The severity of intellectual disability (ID) is primarily determined by adaptive functioning in three domains: conceptual, social, and practical. The level of support required in daily life activities, communication, and social interactions are key indicators of the severity of ID.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Mild ID: Incorrect. Individuals with mild ID can develop social and vocational skills and may achieve up to 6th-grade academic skills. They may live independently with community and social support.

 

Option B. Moderate ID: Incorrect. Individuals may learn basic self-care skills and practical skills for daily living. They may achieve up to 2nd-grade academic skills and require moderate support.

 

Option D. Profound ID: Incorrect. Individuals have pervasive impairments and need a caregiver for all daily living activities. They may have some ability to respond to physical and social activities but require constant, high-level support.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Individuals with severe intellectual disability exhibit profound deficits in communication and social skills, require extensive support in some daily living activities, and have minimal to no functional academic skills.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents who report that while he speaks fluently and comfortably at home, he consistently refrains from speaking in specific social situations, particularly at school, despite understanding and being able to communicate in those settings. They notice he tends to avoid speaking in front of his classmates and teachers. His academic performance is good, and there are no other behavioral concerns. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Childhood anxiety disorder

 

Option D:

 

The presentation of a 10-year-old boy who speaks fluently and comfortably at home but consistently refrains from speaking in specific social situations, such as at school, is indicative of Selective Mutism, which is categorized as a type of childhood anxiety disorder. Selective Mutism is characterized by a child's inability to speak in certain social settings despite having the ability to speak and speaking in other settings (like at home). It's not due to a lack of knowledge or comfort with the spoken language. Instead, it is associated with anxiety and fear about speaking in certain social environments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Childhood depression: While children with depression might be less communicative, the specific pattern of speaking comfortably in some settings (like home) but not in others (like school) is more characteristic of Selective Mutism associated with anxiety, rather than depression.

 

Option B. Hyperkinetic disorder: Also known as Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), hyperkinetic disorder is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. The child's behavior, as described, does not suggest ADHD.

 

Option C. Childhood psychosis: Childhood psychosis involves a loss of contact with reality, such as hallucinations or delusions. The boy's behavior does not indicate psychosis but rather a specific pattern of anxiety-driven mutism in certain social settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selective mutism is more common in children and is comparatively less common in adolescents/adults. It is characterised by a consistent failure to speak in one or more specific social situations (usually the school setting) while speaking fluently in other more familiar situations, such as at home. Treatment includes SSRIs and CBT (cognitive behavioural therapy).

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 201.

choices.text: Parents with a history of depression

questions.text: A 13-year-old patient, who has been a victim of sexual abuse, is admitted for a comprehensive evaluation. In assessing the risk factors for the potential development of a depressive disorder in the future, which of the following is least likely to be influential?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Low cognitive function

 

Option C:

 

Low cognitive function: While low cognitive function can impact the overall mental health and well-being of an individual, it is not as directly influential in the development of depression after traumatic events as the other factors listed. It is more related to intellectual disabilities and difficulties in learning rather than predisposing to mood disorders.

 

 

Explanation:

 

In the context of the development of depressive disorders following traumatic events such as sexual abuse, the factors listed can play a role. However, when evaluating them:

 

Option A. Negative attitude towards abuse indicates that the victim recognizes the event as harmful or wrong. This recognition might provide a foundation for better coping and resilience.

 

Option B. Parents with a history of depression: A familial history of depression (parents with depression) is a known risk factor for depression in offspring, due to a combination of genetic, biological, and environmental factors.

 

Option D. Abuse was penetrative: The nature and severity of the abuse, especially if it was penetrative, can significantly influence the psychological impact on the victim and increase the risk of depressive disorders.

 

Given the provided options, low cognitive function is the least likely to influence the development of a depressive disorder in this patient following sexual abuse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While multiple factors can influence the risk of developing depression after traumatic events, the nature of the traumatic event itself, familial history, and the victim's perception play more direct roles than cognitive function.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 174-175.

questions.text: An 9-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her parents, who are concerned about her recurrent complaints of feeling sick every morning on school days. She often becomes tearful and distressed before school and frequently visits the school nurse, reporting headaches and stomach pains. Her school attendance is affected, with her missing school or being picked up early by her mother at least once a week. A thorough evaluation by her pediatrician, including necessary investigations, has ruled out any organic causes for her symptoms. Interestingly, her parents report that she is usually symptom-free on weekends, but similar symptoms arise if her parents plan to go out and leave her with a babysitter. Based on this presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Separation anxiety disorder

 

Option A:

 

The child's presentation of recurrent complaints of physical symptoms (headaches and stomach pains) predominantly on school days, becoming tearful and distressed before school, and similar symptoms when her parents plan to leave her with a babysitter, is indicative of separation anxiety disorder. Children with separation anxiety disorder experience excessive anxiety concerning separation from home or from those to whom the child is attached. The anxiety exceeds what is expected for the child's developmental level and interferes with school attendance or other daily activities. The fact that the symptoms are primarily observed on school days and when separated from parents but absent on weekends further supports this diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Major depressive disorder: While children with depression can exhibit somatic complaints, the pattern of symptoms primarily on school days and in anticipation of separation from parents is more characteristic of separation anxiety.

 

Option C. Somatization disorder: This involves multiple physical complaints without a medical explanation, but these symptoms would typically be more persistent and not as closely linked to separation situations.

 

Option D. Attachment disorder: This disorder relates to disturbances in social relationships and attachment due to inadequate caregiving experiences, which is not clearly indicated in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Separation anxiety disorder is more common in children and is comparatively less common in adolescents/adults. It is characterized by a persistent and excessive fear of separation from prominent attachment figures (such as parents), which manifests in the form of reluctance to go to school, work, or away from home, or sleep in a separate room. If separation happens, the child may experience physical symptoms such as abdominal pain or headache and fear that something bad will happen to the attachment figures or to self. Treatment includes SSRIs and CBT.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 194-195.
